Award.AwardTitle: CHS: Small: Toward a New Generation of Untethered Magnetic Haptic Interfaces

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will advance the science and technology of magnetic-levitation-based haptic interfaces by developing an untethered hand-held interface in which magnetic forces are applied to a freely moving tool rather than a handle that is physically attached to a larger device. The project will extend force-feedback devices into a new wave of development that incorporates free mobility. Current haptic devices use mechanically linkages to impart forces and torques to the user. These new untethered devices will use projected magnetic fields and an externally tracked tool so that the user is freed from any physical linkage. The project will contribute to the development of new microsurgical systems that can be used to train and evaluate novice surgeons prior to conducting surgery on actual patients.

This project will investigate a new type of magnetic haptic interface, an untethered magnetic interface that renders force/torque to a permanent magnet attached to a stylus by using electromagnets that project their magnetic fields into free space. The position and orientation of the permanent magnet must be tracked to provide feedback for the device to work as a haptic interface. Unlike Lorentz-force interfaces, which must encase a portion of the stylus, the project will produce an untethered interface in which the stylus can be completely removed from the electromagnet system, thus eliminating the physical linkage between the haptic stylus and the rest of the system, and reducing stylus inertia to only that of the stylus itself. The project has three goals: (1) To develop the analytical relationships that will govern untethered magnetic haptic interfaces. Many of the existing basic principles for haptic devices will need to be reconsidered, such the fundamental trade-offs among workspace size, stylus inertia, maximum force/torque generation, maximum stable surface stiffness, and sampling update rate. (2) To adapt high-speed image-processing techniques to track the six degrees of freedom of movement that are possible in an untethered manual tool. (3) To realize a prototype magnetic haptic interface that is optimized for simulating cataract surgery.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project involved the design and control of untethered magnetic haptic devices. A "haptic device" is a type of force-feedback joystick that enables a human user to physically interact with a virtual environment. Haptic devices are typically constructed as small desktop robots, but the mass and friction in their links and joints makes it difficult to render certain types of virtual-reality simulations, such as microsurgery. In an untethered magnetic haptic device, forces and torques are applied magnetically, eliminating the need for a traditional linkage. To realize such a device, a great deal of new knowledge was generated.

Intellectual Merit:

This project created new methods to construct multi-coil electromagnet systems. Such systems are typically designed with a high degree of symmetry, but this does not leave sufficient room for a hand-held tool to enter the workspace and for cameras to see the workspace, both of which are required for use as a haptic device. A new "open asymmetric" eight-coil system was designed, which greatly increases access to the workspace with minimal impact on system performance. In addition, a paradigm-shifting ceramic frame enables the heat generated in the coils to be dissipated efficiently. 

In multi-coil electromagnet systems, the standard method to solve for the currents required to achieve some desired magnetic force and torque does not account for the temperature in the electromagnets, nor does it sufficiently account for the saturation limits of the amplifiers and power supply, both of which limit the system's overall performance in practice. In this project, an improved current-solving method was developed, which increases both the achievable output magnitudes and the total operating time to achieve those outputs, while eliminating the risk of overheating. 

A perennial challenge when rendering a virtual surface with a haptic interface is making the surface feel rigid without destroying its realism, since simply increasing its stiffness can lead to vibration-inducing instability. One way to increase the perceived hardness without increasing stiffness is to implement a force braking pulse when the haptic device first makes contact with the virtual environment, but there are practical limits to the strength of the force pulse. In this project, nonrealistic moment (i.e., torque) pulses are rendered very briefly during the contact event, which exploits a new haptic illusion, and utilizes previously underutilized actuators. A virtual surface rendered with these hybrid force-moment braking pulses is perceived as harder than the same virtual surface rendered with a traditional force braking pulse, without harming the surface's realism, for the majority of users.

When humans haptically interact with objects using a tool, they use high-frequency vibrations sensed in the skin to identify the object's texture and to inform estimates of other material properties. The human hand detects high-frequency vibrations in all directions but cannot distinguish the direction, which suggests a multi-dimensional vibrotactile stimulus is haptically equivalent to some one-dimensional (1D) stimulus. In haptic rendering, we have the opportunity to create the illusion of a given stimulus at a given frequency by providing a different stimulus that will be perceived as having the same intensity. This project described how to think about stylus-based vibrotactile display as the 6D problem that it is, with up to three orthogonal forces and up to three orthogonal torques rendered to the device. A psychophysical study was performed to determine detection thresholds over the frequency range 20-250 Hz. It was discovered that people are less sensitive to force signals parallel to the stylus than to those orthogonal to the stylus at low frequencies, and far more sensitive to torque signals about the stylus than to those orthogonal to the stylus. Minimal-parameter models were found to describe the frequency-dependent thresholds for each of the principal force and torque modes. Finally, the mapping from a 6D vibrotactile stimulus to an equivalent 1D stimulus was discovered. 

Broader Impact:

The principle proposed application of the technology and methodology supported by this award is the accurate rendering and training of microsurgeries, specifically eye surgeries. The goal is to enable surgeons to be better prepared when they conduct their first surgery on an actual patient.

In the pursuit of an untethered magnetic haptic device with the best performance possible, many different aspects of magnetic actuation and haptics were fundamentally reconsidered, and as a result, many of the results of the project will have a broad impact beyond untethered magnetic haptic interfaces. The results related to vibrotactile haptic feedback and haptic illusions are broadly applicable to most haptic devices, including those that are commercially available. The results related to magnetic actuation are broadly applicable to the microrobotics and medical-robotics communities. 

In addition, 17 students (three graduate students and 14 undergraduate students) received training and mentorship from this project. The research for two PhD students' dissertations and one MS student's thesis was supported by this award.
